history.content:
I can comment on EE 127 vs. CS 189.

CS 189 has a lot more breadth. On one hand, it introduces a lot of different machine learning algorithms. On the other hand, it talks about some statistical inference (MLE, MAP) and a bit of optimization, a bit of information theory, a bit of learning theory, etc. The main ideas you take away from the course are the various methods, a sense of how to use them (how to program them), and various motivations for why they were created.

EE 127 can be summarized as: a review of linear algebra (you may not have seen all of this stuff before: norms, dual norms, SVD), knowledge of common convex models (and how to program them), and some techniques for taking a generic optimization problem and manipulating it into a convex problem. (Generally speaking, convex problems are tractable and non-convex problems are not; there are exceptions.) I think it provides a good foundation for CS 189.

children.subject: If you're not comfortable with linear algebra/multivariate calculus, I would personally say 127. You will need a working knowledge of probability (continuous probability with Gaussians, especially) but you could potentially get by with a review of 70, since 189 tends to teach the new probability concepts (MLE/MAP/information theory).
If one was taking one course out of {126, 127} as a prep for 189, which would be recommended ?

history.content:
Is taking both Stat 154 and CS 189 (not in the same semester, probably 154 first then 189) a waste of time? I only ask since they're both listed as ML courses, and was wondering if taking both of them would be worthwhile.

Also, if anyone's taken 154, 189, and EE 127, what exactly are the differences in these classes? Thank you.
history.subject: Taking both Stat 154 and CS 189 waste of time?
